awd_titl_txt: Resolving Source Contributions to Atmospheric Deposition
awd_abstract_narration:
The primary objective of this research project is to improve understanding of how pollutants containing nitrogen deposit into water bodies from the atmosphere. This project directly benefits society by addressing water quality and ecosystem health concerns. These water quality concerns include low oxygen levels and acidic conditions that can result in loss of life in aquatic systems.  This research provides a beneficial tool for improving watershed management. The researchers are seeking to confirm that the emission source for these pollutants can be hundreds of miles away from the water body that is affected. This project supports the training of a Ph.D. student and also engages undergraduate chemical engineering students in research and community outreach activities. In addition, undergraduate students participate in undergraduate research experiences and service-learning projects through partnerships with Connecticut state parks and technical high schools. The project engages the community through monitoring activities that take place at several high schools and state parks.

An atmospheric chemical transport model coupled with a watershed model will account for source-resolved pollutant transport across multiple components of the watershed system. The researchers are studying deposition estimates to different watersheds and regional linking with a watershed model over the Connecticut River Watershed. A goal of this research project is to transform watershed and ecosystem management by creating an essential source-resolved bridge between two interacting earth systems: the atmosphere and hydrosphere. This research represents a substantial step forward by providing a comprehensive evaluation of impacts to watersheds throughout the country and developing overarching estimates of the impacts of air pollution on soil and water quality. Results of this project provide societal benefits by addressing water quality and ecosystem health concerns. These water quality concerns include hypoxia which negatively impacts fisheries and acidification which can result in loss of life in aquatic systems. This research also provides a beneficial tool for improving watershed management plan development.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: Nitrogen is an essential nutrient for plant growth and aquatic life. Excess nitrogen, often from human activities (such as fossil-fuel burning, animal production and waste, and fertilizer use), can cause harmful impacts on ecosystems. These include excessive algae growth, deforestation, biodiversity loss, hypoxia, acidification, and eutrophication. One source of nitrogen in natural systems is the deposition of atmospheric nitrogen-containing pollutants. Winds can transport atmospheric nitrogen over long distances. The atmospheric nitrogen can then deposit to terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems. Deposition is difficult to measure because it depends on many localized factors (such as terrain) and there are not sufficient observation stations to capture this variability. Regional air quality models provide the opportunity to estimate deposition over large scales and identify the major sources contributing to atmospheric nitrogen concentrations and deposition. This information is important when designing effective regulatory measures to combat negative ecosystem impacts.

Methods: We used a regional air quality model to estimate the contribution from major sources to atmospheric nitrogen deposition in the contiguous United States (US). We evaluated model performance by comparing modeled estimates with observations from national networks. The model performed well except over large waterbodies, such as the Great Lakes. We collected passive deposition samples throughout the states of Connecticut and New York.

Results: First, we evaluated the impact major source categories (for instance, vehicular emissions, agriculture, and electricity generation) have on atmospheric nitrogen deposition. The central US receives substantial total nitrogen deposition, mostly reduced nitrogen from agricultural sources. The northeastern US experiences substantial total nitrogen, mainly oxidized nitrogen from vehicles. Overall, the western US experiences less nitrogen deposition than much of the rest of the country.

Second, we evaluated the major regions contributing to atmospheric nitrogen deposition. Emissions from the Upper Mississippi and Ohio Hydrologic Units (2-digit codes) had the biggest impacts on deposition within their region and experienced the highest levels of deposition overall. Emissions from these regions also substantially contribute to deposition in adjacent regions due to pollutant transport. Nationally, about 40% of nitrogen deposition resulted from long-range transport of pollutants from other regions.

Finally, we evaluated the impact of emissions from major metropolitan areas on atmospheric nitrogen deposition. Of the metropolitan areas we studied, emissions from the New York City, NY area had the biggest impact on nitrogen deposition in the surrounding regions. Emissions from the San Francisco, CA area contributed disproportionately to the deposition in that part of the country. This indicates that nitrogen emissions from the San Francisco, CA area are more likely to deposition than those from other cities. Our novel deposition sampling approach was too prone to contamination to provide any definitive results.

Broader Impacts: This project helped train two PhD students and twelve undergraduate researchers. Throughout the sampling, we partnered with nature centers throughout the region to host the samplers and provide opportunities for members of the community to see the sampling approach at work.

Outcomes: This work provides specific estimates of atmospheric nitrogen deposition both spatially and temporally in the contiguous United States and demonstrates a framework that is transferrable to other regions and spatial scales to track major sources of atmospheric pollutant deposition. This information will help to develop improved frameworks that guide environmental regulators toward the most effective and efficient paths to protect human health and the environment from the negative impacts of atmospheric pollutants.
